newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico Jan consumer prices rose 2.57 percent.
newsitem.headline: Mexico Jan consumer prices rose 2.57 percent.

text.p: Mexico's consumer price index rose 2.57 percent in January from the month before after rising 3.20 percent in December, Banco de Mexico said.
The central bank added that the producer price index rose 2.29 percent in January from the month before, compared to rise of 2.66 percent in December.
The monthly inflation was slightly above expectations of a rise of 2.40 percent in a Reuters survey of nine Mexican brokerages and research companies.
The central bank said that compared with the same month a year earlier the CPI was 26.44 percent higher.

It said that the main causes of inflation during January were an increase in prices of tortilla and tortilla dough, fresh milk, housing, cars, car insurance and registration, limes, green tomatoes, bananas, zucchini, peas, grapes and avocados, restaurants, urban transport, domestic gas and local telephone service.
It said that the basic basket of consumer goods rose 2.37 percent in January from the month before.
Banco de Mexico gave the following breakdown for January:
In January, the producer price index, excluding petroleum, was 23.69 percent higher than the same month a year earlier.
Banco de Mexico said that of the 46 cities where it collects information for the consumer price index, the greatest increases were seen in the following:
